title: Between 1 January 2018 and 30 June 2018, how many reports of traffic accidents involving an autonomous vehicle will the California Department of Motor Vehicles receive?
preds: You know...   This is why you need to trust your math/system and just stick with it.   I changed my mind almost a dozen times on this question because I started to get nervous every now and then.  We're currently at 22, I had 21.23.   https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/725087
Based on the June 14th current report date, accidents should have been reported through June 4th; but not sure the Cal DMV up to date on its reporting (last reported accident s May 25th).
May was an accident heavy month it seems. I don't believe it's possible that there will be 10 more in the remaining weeks.

As of this morning's update they had hit 20, with 6 accidents in May and none reported for June yet.   A few weeks ago they repealed one after reporting it, so that could still happen, but 20 still looks like a shoo-in.
Pick and stick I didn't. Shaped down like others when it wasn't going to be in line for 20-29. Ugh

This is a lesson on overfitting for me. I had initially centered on 20-29 based on past frequency and expected trends, but then betrayed my analysis and went for 10-19 after not seeing accidents for a while. Ah well.

Current data indicates 18 as of the June 5th report.  The question material (More Info, below) points out that companies have 10 days to report to the California DMV after an accident.  --> IT is possible possible that accidents from May 26th have not been reported yet on the website.  Sticking with a higher forecast since GM Cruise were involved in a string of accidents, including May 22, 23 and 25.
Shifting a little lower because I don't think we get three more crashes in the next two weeks.

If we assume the CA DMV data is, as advertised, only good through June 5, you could calculate an accident rate from January 1 to then, multiple by the days to June 30, giving 20.9 accidents in the question period. However, the press has been covering autonomous vehicle accidents pretty enthusiastically. If you assume 18 accidents is actually good through today, then that calculation changes to just under 20.
Another crazy cliff hanger, makes it fun though.  Get some forecaster's heart-rates going.
Had 20-29 at 75% for a couple months. 5% 30-39. Moving that 5% down to 20 bracket.
Actual is 18, and monthly average is comfortably above 3.  Only one month has had only 1;  next lowest is 2.

4 for May bring it up to 18. Three of the May accidents were the fault of another driver and the fourth was the driver of a Cruise putting the car into reverse instead of drive. Not a forecasting complaint but one about the lag. A week ago they had just released the 15th accident from May 13. Now within a week they have released reports from 22 - 25. After following this question since December it is frustrating. The reporting lag has peen pretty even until this last month.
Now 17. Up 2. So could get to 19 or 20 by June 30th.
At 17 with 3.5 weeks to go. Hard to guess given latency - but does go to July 20 to account for that. Guessing right around 20?
As of today 15 are registred; after a March surge the frequency has significantly dropped, also reflecting a more cautious approach by testers, occasionally involving postponement.

15 from back on May 13. Big reporting lag on this one. And the link isn't working yet so you can't see the accident details.
One a week through June would move into the next bin but that doesn't seem very likely right now.

Averaging around 3 per month in 2018,
Since a streak of 6 accidents in March in 15 days; only two reported in the past two months.
Recent negative publicity after the first fatality may have increased safety precautions by companies.

15 (ShivaDiva) or 14 still?  Anyhow may be due to less driving, or the safety drivers are now required to you know 'play safe' which is their role, and be extra cautious and just brake when pedestrains are about to be hit rather than let the computer do everything.  Amazing case study of psychology. This AI future is just nuts.  89-11 to 95-5 due to very slim chance of there being 5 crashes in one month.
Assuming 10 days compliance and 5 days to post said compliance paperwork on the website (questionable assumption) & ppois() model at mu=19*2
Have Californians suddenly become better drivers?

WoC0.56 & 0.37 Wonder when the next crash in CA will be? Seems the previous crashes have been due to overconfidence in the magic box. If the safety drivers had been skeptics with anxiety the accidents would not have happened. They'd have tapped the brakes or hit the big red button. A lesson not to let massive bias in your tests. Nut hopefully they'll learn sooner going down the optimistic faithful route. Mainstream retail drivers are supposed to just let go and trust the new whiz-bang gadget, so it really needs to be biased towards sloppiness and getting it as accurate and safe as possible.  Now ignoring my own advice as I have no data on whether hours and mileage per car has increased or more cars are out there, or if the software tweaks will help fix it enough, (the time invested to find and read the data outweighs getting some brier points gain) I'm going to make a wild guess that there just won't be another 5 crashes in 5 weeks. Perhaps it might get to 16, 17, 18 though.  Look forward to July 20th.
14 so far. The California DMV hasn't updated  the list in a month.

As of today, there are 14 reported accidents on in the relevant database.  It is no longer possible that the <10 range could be accurate.   It is Hugely unlikely that in the time remaining there will be a large enough jump to cross into the 20-29 range, but it is possible.  I don't believe that there is any chance at all that the number will more than double in the remaining time.

This lull has shifted towards a new measurement. For the year 14 accidents / 135 days so far this year = 0.1037 accidents /day. With 46 days left that is another ~4.77 accidents. Thus 18 - 19. (The reporting lag is not factored into this.)
Before this big lull I was fairly confident it would just get over the threshold of 20. Now I am less certain. 
Again it's not the autonomous car it is simply miles on the road and other drivers.
Updating on the lack of new accidents since April 4 (there is about a two week lag between an accident and it being reported on the website).
We’ve been stuck at 14 longer than most Trump appointees have served (ba dum dum). Starting to question if we’ll even hit 20.

https://www.dmv.ca.gov/portal/dmv/detail/vr/autonomous/autonomousveh_ol316+
Current reading is 14, at this run rate 20 21 is the most likely outcome

https://orfe.princeton.edu/.../SmartDrivingCars/.../RAND_TestingAV_HowManyMiles.p...
Google did 1.3 million miles with 11 accidents up to 2015.  I'll guess the systems are better - that the real issue is someone else hitting the driverless car.  I'm going with 4 accidents per million miles.
Now 50 companies doing driverless in CA.  Google has a fleet of 50. Fully driverless testing allowed from april of this year.  I'll guess there were 100 cars for the first 120 days and the average will be 10 cars per fleet or 500 driverless vehicles for the second 90 days.
I'll guess the average car does 200 miles per day.  
100 cars * 200 miles per day * 120 days = 2.4 million miles x 4 accidents per million miles = 9.6
500 cars * 200 mpd * 90 days = 9 million miles x 4 accidents per million = 36
total 46
Even with a very safe April. 14 accidents in 4 months is 3.5 per month. Which is 21 for 6 months. I know it's not that simple but I'm staying put for a few more weeks on my forecast.
At 14 2018.05.01 with less than 9 weeks. In 3 months there were 12 - likely going to be around 20 or slightly higher

Update on data: As of today there are 14 recorded (see https://www.dmv.ca.gov/portal/dmv/detail/vr/autonomous/autonomousveh_ol316  )
Based on my previous rationale numbers are adjusted to reflect the trajectory.
Well we are up to 14 accidents so I am shifting a few points higher.
New assumption mu=38, based off of GM Cruise crash reporting, the population of autonomous cars rose dramatically ~June 2017
14 accidents so far. Mostly GM Cruise in San Francisco, as expected. 40 days to go. Expecting another 5 accidents, so this could come down to the wire.
14 total, about 4 per month, closer to 50 50 that it will get to 20

14
A Waymo car was rear ended while stopped at a red light.
Another one added; 14 as of April 6th.  I revised my math to weight the recent activity before and after the Uber incident, and it looks like they're going to end up at 21.23 by June 30th.

No new accidents since end of March increases the likelihood of the second bin (which I had initially as too low anyway, justifying an update). To get into the second bin we need slightly more than 1 accident in two weeks. Granted, the rate of accidents is not monotonic and there can be slow periods and packed periods.
adjusting mu=29 from 27 to accomadate larger self driving vehicle pop. Still assuming Poisson dist.

Af of April 6, we are at 13. The amount of driving (e.g. as expressed in vehicle miles traveled) has a seasonal component and tends to rise in the Spring and Summer (https://www.bts.gov/explore-topics-and-geography/topics/seasonally-adjusting-vehicle-miles-traveled). Pedestrians are also more likely to be outside. These factors increase the risks of accidents, suggesting that the rate of accidents would probably rise (all else being equal).
Many of the accidents aren’t the result of autonomous cars but bad drivers in other vehicles. Regardless, still counts. Half way in and we’re at 13.
Up to 13...  Been a really crappy few weeks for GM.

Eleven by 4 April takes few than 10 out.   Take it as a toss-up whether the rate slows or
accelerates a bit.  If it rises much, perhaps AVs will be reconsidered by either the regulators or
their owners.  (Yes, grammatical ambiguity crept in there.)

13 now. We are definitely out of the lull. I was beginning to think I was too high on the 20-29 range. Now I feel I may need to increase it more.
5 January
2 February
6 March Think of the reverse. Already at 13; what are the odds there will be fewer than 6 accidents over the next 3 months?
I assume everyone is re-calibrating their sw after recent events. Which means fewer logged test miles which translates to fewer accidents.
Jeepers - not a good few weeks for Chevy.
11. The most recent two were again caused by a driver rear ending the Cruise in autonomous mode. Still very surprising that 18% say there will be fewer than 10 accidents.
About halfway through and we’re at 11. Likely within a few either way of 20.
while it is clear, autonomous vehicles cannot be safe, the increase in accidentality may increase the human driver carefulnes for a short timespan.
5 accidents in January, 2 in Feb, 2 in Jan

Updating using numbers from March 30th. The probability seems to be shifting towards the smaller accident numbers. I'm still using the model described here : https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/700698 that now gives the figure shown here : https://www.dropbox.com/s/vz411oqfumjjjrw/prob.png?dl=0.
reducing my probability of a high number - expect greater scrutiny and care to be taken after the incident involving Uber.
9th. Cruise in autonomous mode hit by another car.
Initial cast based on 2017 data, assuming this is a Poisson distribution and lambda=27

According to California's DMV, there have been 9 accidents through 30 March 2018. There are double the amount of permits for companies driving autonomous cars now than there were a year ago. Accidents should increase as vehicle and pedestrian traffic increases with nicer weather.  Extrapolating from accidents and time, you get 18 through 30 June. Extrapolating based on permits gets you to 36. However, being an optimist about technology and automation, I expect it to be performing better the more data it has, so let's say it's somewhere in between ('between 20 and 29, inclusive').

From Jan 1 - Mar 14 already 8 incidents have occurred. Without a reason to assume any major increase or major decrease in incidents, conservative estimate would be 100% between 10 and 19, thus continuing the general trend. Is there a possibility of more companies doing tests in California in 2018? More research into the market would be needed. Reason for forecast: Messed around in Excel a bit.
Foresee a decrease in the rate of accidents, based on a temporary lull in the amount of public testing following the recent string of fatal/near-fatal accidents.

As the end date draws nearer, the potential for the number in increase drastically diminishes.  I no longer think it is worth considering that there will be enough new accidents for the total to increase beyond 19. It's still possible that there will be fewer than 10, but that seems unlikely given the past trends.

8th for the year. Cruise in autonomous mode was struck by another car.
I know there is a reporting lag but today is the halfway point and there are 8 reports as of now.

BAM!   I love it when that happens.  The tally was updated today and they're now at 8 reports.   "The average is 21.3 days between accidents."  https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/716087 February 20th to March 14th was 22 day.  :)

After the Arizona fatality, slightly increased chance of fewer autonomous miles driven (from company side or regulatory side). This would tend to force overall accidents downward, as I understand them to be incredibly rare.
We’re up to 8 total (1in March).also there can be a 2 week lag...
Most of March gone without accidents

DMV results haven't been updated but thorough internet search shows its been fairly safe for the self driving cars lately.  Revising numbers downward.  Here's some numbers I quickly crunched:  https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/716087

https://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2018/03/27/597331608/arizona-suspends-ubers-self-driving-vehicle-testing-after-fatal-crash
This doesn't really affect my reasoning I just thought others might be interested. Just because Uber isn't testing doesn't mean others aren't. Also the seven incidents so far this year are very diverse in nature and have not been the fault of the autonomous car.

Suspensions of tests likely to depress accident rates. Dateline 3-27-2018 http://www.autonews.com/article/20180327/MOBILITY/180329678/nvidia-testing-autonomous-uber-fatality
Dateline 3-27-2018 https://www.nytimes.com/2018/03/27/technology/uber-self-driving-cars-california.html
7 this year five last year seems on track for same number by July : 14
slow sales and less accidents from Jan to March compared to last year
Anyway you slice it, $500 per month is a lot of money for a mainstream vehicle that you pretty much can’t take outside of the state of California

Updating on the same premises, with more weight on the 10-19 mark as latest developments may intensify research & sandbox testing before live testing. Also, for the same reason, better results are expected.
Scaling back my estimates as expect recent accident will cause all efforts to regroup before continuing.
Not sure how recent events will impact GM (will they scale back/be more careful even though most incidents caused by non-autonomous vehicles?). Going heavier on the 10-19 grouping.

There are only two players of note in California:  Waymo (google) and Cruise (GM).  Waymo has shifted half of its cars to Phoenix: 
https://www.theverge.com/2018/1/31/16956902/california-dmv-self-driving-car-disengagement-2017 Waymo drove 400k miles, 8k miles between disengagements.  Or 50 disengagements.
Cruise drove 131K miles, disengaging 105 times; rapidly improving.  April 2 a CA law no longer requires safety drivers.  That said, I think a fatality (such as happened in Arizona) will result in huge decreases of miles driven for a time as the involved company shuts down for examination of what happens.   Waymo, Cruise.   No other company broke 10 k miles tested in CA.  50% through the testing period, 6 accidents reported.    GM rapidly increasing miles between disengagments. 
However.   In the last reporting session, zero accidents were caused by GM.   Other drivers were at fault in all cases.   So there is a certain baseline of miles (165000 miles per VMT) between accidents.    So stastically 11-12 accidents.

First fatal accident (in Arizona) involving an autonomous vehicle, though it sounds like the car was probably not at fault: https://www.reuters.com/article/us-autos-selfdriving-uber/self-driving-uber-car-kills-arizona-woman-crossing-street-idUSKBN1GV296

Removal of self-driving Uber vehicles from all U.S. roads is likely to reduce total accidents, especially if other experimenters follow suit. Dateline 3-19-2018 Uber has removed its self-driving cars from the roads following what is believed to be the first fatality involving a fully autonomous car. -- http://money.cnn.com/2018/03/19/technology/uber-autonomous-car-fatal-crash/index.html
Death reduces likely levels of driving in next few weeks or beyond, reducing likely total crashes
Seven so far, mostly those GM Cruises in San Francisco.

As of March 6, 2018, the DMV has received 59 Autonomous Vehicle Collision Reports.
Assume more companies doing more testing is the trend and a commitment to report continues.

As of today - 13 March - there have been 7 reported accidents in the DMV database.  It seems unlikely but possible that software improvements and warmer weather could lead to there being fewer accidents in the remaining months.  It also seems even more unlikely that the rate of accidents will increase enough that there will be more than 12 more reported in the remaining time allowed.

"As of March 6, 2018, the DMV has received 59 Autonomous Vehicle Collision Reports"
Is it 59 nation wide? So where do I find the figures for California?  OK so it's a typo, should be 2014 right? Only been 7 in 2018 if you count each one.  So June 30 is a while away. 7 GM Cruise February 20, 2018 6 GM Cruise February 16, 2018 5 Drive.ai, Inc. January 29, 2018 4 GM Cruise January 28, 2018 3 Zoox January 18, 2018 2 GM Cruise January 8, 2018 1 GM Cruise January 2, 2018  what is it with these Cruise drivers? Need data on if they replace with another Cruise and then crash it again, that would be comical. I imagine they might want a different car.  Now I need to know how many vehicles with AI there is in Ca.  Does it still count each one if 2 self-driving cars crash in to each other or is that one? What about a pile up?  Is 'oops your Honour I was hacked' count too?  Seriously, I'm just extrapolating that it's half way, so doubling 7 gets 14. A bit silly, but that's all I can go on. I can't really change it much because factoring in weather/traffic seasons gives a plus and a minus that cancels each other out. California doesn't really have winter, but perhaps rains may play some role?
Slight adjustment based on 7 in two months. No fantastic insight on my part, just some simple math on my end. The lag in reporting (DMV) is annoying...
Shifting higher because at a rate of seven crashes every two months we end up around 21 accidents.

Seventh for the year right on the heels of the sixth. 
How fewer than 10 crashes is still 17% of all responses is a little surprising to me.

I guess not everyone welcomes our robotic overlords...
https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2018/mar/06/california-self-driving-cars-attacked
They've already had 6 and it's only March 5th.  :)

According to the CA DMV, there were over 500,000 miles of autonomous driving reported between 12/16-11/17. The two most active companies were Waymo and GM. During this 1 year span, there were 26 accident for an average accident rate of 1:19k miles. Assuming that companies continue to test at 50k autonomous miles/month, this translates to an average of 2.6 accidents/month. This rate, coupled with 6 accidents already reported for Jan + Feb 2018, gives us a predicted total of 16. Factors that may increase this prediction:
1) GM + Waymo test significantly more miles, increasing chances for collisions
2) Less experienced companies test more miles Factors that may decrease this prediction:
1) GM + Waymo develop safer systems using previous experience
2) GM + Waymo test fewer miles (unlikely) https://www.dmv.ca.gov/portal/dmv/detail/vr/autonomous/disengagement_report_2017
The rate is doubling every year. I expect 60+ for 2018.
People will drive into autonomous vehicles. I predict that no incident will be a failure of the autonomous vehicle.

Two months and 6 reported (maybe another will trickle in given lag). Going to back down a little - rough call points to around 20 (only roughly factoring increased summer travel, extra autonomous cars on road etc). They are still a relatively small % of vehicles out there...
Updating with data published Feb 28th using same model as previous forecasts that accounts for accidents occurring and not occurring.

There were 27 such accidents last year (15 in 2016) and there are more autonomous vehicles on the road, but we are dealing with a 6 month period of time. There were 5 accidents reported in January 2018, none so far in February though I think there must be a data lag unless it's an outlier month. I'm assuming seasonality doesn't matter because it's Cali, everyone drives all the time. I don't know how many such cars are on the road or what sales are like, but since it's a pretty new field and trendy I think it's reasonable to assume at least the same rate of growth as there was from 2016 to 2017, this would project to about 50 accidents for the year of 2018. This number is probably conservative. We'll probably end up with a number between 20 and 29 for the question period, with a higher probability that the number is higher than that, rather than lower.
It is inevitable with more and more autonomous cars on the road, that they will be involved in more accidents.

The California DMV has allowed the testing and deployment of driverless vehicles on April 2018. This regulation will open the floodgates and allow companies to push the boundaries of what is possible and give them "license" to test different driving modes. Moreover, as research in this phase heats up, more and more companies will be eager to test more vehicles. The combination of number of vehicles, different driving modes, and risk taking by researchers will significantly increase the number of accidents on the road. However, as safety is one of the key tenets of autonomous car research, these accidents will likely be minor ones (like being rear-ended, etc), and result from autonomous vehicles not behaving exactly as a car being driven by a person would in certain circumstances.

Few factors to consider before just extrapolating past experience:
- More miles driven
- New players in the industry (e.g. Drive.ai, Inc.)
- Software getting better
- There has previously never been any accident in January: more aggressive testing this year? I am leaning towards a fairly stable number of accidents this year to last year.
5 accidents matching the guidelines occurred between May and September 2017.

using Website https://www.dmv.ca.gov/portal/dmv/detail/vr/autonomous/autonomousveh_ol316+ as a source 
Last year there were 27 accidents, so 2.25 ish a month. This year there have been 5 already, running above average. One should expect the pace to go up as the miles driven go up as well.
At the same pace as last year there will be 15 accidents until June. If the pace of 2018 continues there will be 18/19 accidents

Prediction based on constant daily probability of accidents between September 2017 (break in previously linear curve) and now. All data available here : https://www.dropbox.com/s/6uad0yt7i054a41/AVAccidents.xlsx?dl=0. This prediction will be updated with each new data point. NOTE THAT :
- The assumption of linearity is weak at best. Will need to be followed closely. If the rate changes significantly (another break), then may need to re-evaluate period of relevant data for prediction. 
- The numbers  take into account both that accidents happen and that they don't happen. To account for the reporting delay, I only take into account data (or data absence) up to the last DMV update minus the 10 legal days for reporting.
- The numbers forecast are (for now) entirely data driven. I do not have enough visibility on AV policy and California testing policy to factor in other information. For now my hypothesis is that there will be no major change in either (or at least no change large enough to significantly skew my forecast). This forecast has a wider spread than its predecessor, which for now I think is better. The spread should naturally decrease as more data become available. See latest forecast figure here  : https://www.dropbox.com/s/vz411oqfumjjjrw/prob.png?dl=0 (note: this file will be overwritten by newer forecasts).

Prediction based on linear fit to data between September 2017 (break in previously linear curve) and now. All data available here : https://www.dropbox.com/s/6uad0yt7i054a41/AVAccidents.xlsx?dl=0. This prediction will be updated with each new data point. BUT
- The assumption of linearity is weak at best. Will need to be followed closely. If the rate changes significantly (another break), then may need to re-evaluate period of relevant data for prediction.
- The numbers do not take into account the fact that there is a significant delay between accidents happening and the reports being published. This delay seems to be variable (and at times above the legal 10 days), so I cannot evaluate the weight to give to the information that "there have been no accidents recently".

Pattern of increase has been 9,15,29 in 2015-2017. Largely down to number of miles driven, so just assuming rate of increase is similar to last few years. Doubled in 2017 but a high proportion of those still a few producers. So guessing it rises again by 50-100%
27 accidents in 2017 reported - most in 2nd half of 2017.  Expect more to occur in 2018.  5 reported in January
There are few autonomous vehicles on the road and they are under intense scrutiny.
this provides a basis for my previous answer to the question about Audi.
Very few autonomous vehicles in operation which are at the same time overwhelmingly safe. Aggregate probability therefore low.
Not that many vehicles yet, but they are safer
Few Autonomous Vehicles, operated mostly by corporations in testing.  Are on streets, but not yet operated by general public.  Through first month of 2018 there have been 5 accidents.
AI at this early stage will be involved in more accidents than many predict due to irregular behaviors arising from cars with drivers in the presence of driverless cars.
Sept 2018 there were 6 accridents reported in SF
These systems have difficulty adapting to unpredictable driver behavior. As the proliferate, accidents will become more common and liability issues will be fought in the judicial system.
There are very few autonomous vehicles on the road.  So far they have proved to be very efficient at avoiding collisions.

The accidents are more likely to be the result of other vehicle error and the safety features of the autonomous vehicles are already pretty cautious, therefore looking at freak accidents and anomalous situations

5 in January now. Per question, the autonomous vehicle doesn’t have to be at fault or even moving - if part of an accident/damage, it’s reported. I’m thinking high 20’s and if ~5 each month may breach 30.
There is also a seasonal impact - more accidents in last six months (2016 - 33%, 2017 50%).
5th crash on 1/29. A vehicle being driven in manual mode hit construction equipment in the right lane. Sometimes I hate updating this question because it feels like I am rooting for accidents...
Another accident in January, total of 5

My previous analysis was based on visual inspection of the rate of accidents with time. I'm now basing my forecast on the base rate since October 2017 (when the rate picked up significantly), with an uncertainty of 25% on this rate.
These systems are still susceptible to serious bugs. Depending on the number of test vehicles on the road, the number of mishaps will not be as limited as the manufacturers would hope.

One report is a taxi driver slapping the windsheild od an autonomous vehicle.  It was counted as an accident.  Apparently California is loose with what it conciders an accident.  I'll revise my answer as the year progresses.
Because I’m fascinated by the trend of autonomous vehicles as delivery devices.

The technology is not foolproof and California roadways are autobahns of insanity.  The number of self-driving vehicles is very small.  Thus there is likely to be some low number of incidents or accidents per these tens of thousands of miles put on the odometers.
People are using this technology without true understanding its limitations

There were 19 in last 6 months of 2017. There were 4 in January.  Just going by averages/trends would expect around 20. In LA currently (busy highways due to Presidents’ Day weekend) and I was surprised by better use of turn signals and less crazy antics on the roads than I recall in recent past. Are American drivers getting better? Regardless I’m expecting slightly more than 20 given increased numbers. BUT outside of some wealthy enclaves you don’t see many autonomous cars on the road as percentage.

From article by Favaro et al (10.1371/journal.pone.0184952), the number of accidents scales directly with the number of miles traveled : 25 accidents for 1.1 million miles. The question then splits into two parts :  1) How many miles will be travelled in the first 6 months of 2018 ?
2) What is the probability that the rate will stay unchanged ? Part 2 : In the same article, the vast majority (22/26) accidents reported had nothing to do with the automated nature of the vehicles, indicating that the rate is unlikely to plateau or increase due to a fixing a simple problem with the AV system.  There is also a small probability that the rate could drop drastically due to a bad accident. I estimate that at 5% Part 1: This is the more difficult question. 27 accidents in 2017 would be indicative of 27 / 25 x 1.1x10^6 miles. I’ve plotted out accidents as a function of time here : https://www.dropbox.com/s/6uad0yt7i054a41/AVAccidents.xlsx?dl=0. Given the past rate, I would estimate anywhere between 65 and 70 cumulative accidents by June 30th. As by 1st Jan there had been 52 accidents already, that leads to an estimate of between 13 and 23 accidents in the 6 months period.

In January they had 4.   6X4 is 24.  That is the likely outcome.  Very very unlikely it will be less than 10 at this point.  But the manufacturers might, on the fly -- fix some of the problems. during this period so less than 20 might realistically happen.  But if more cars get on the road there might be more than 30.
A small number of crashes caused by human drivers of other cars is probably unavoidable, but the time period is short and the number of vehicles is limited.
Well there were four in the month of January and I expect the GM Cruise to be the gift that keeps on giving. Got to keep an eye on this one, I'm almost worried there will be more than 19 accidents.
Already 4 in January, but none so far in February. Assume between 2 and 5 accidents per month on average with more weight towards 2 or 3.

There have already been some reports of traffic accidents. These have typically been caused by other drivers and with the proliferation of these vehicles I can see that there will be an increase in the number of traffic related incidents.
I think you will find they are going to be a very safe vehicle

This is too crucial a time to prove the validity of the technology.  Hyper caution will be the norm for the next few years.  Nobody wants to be the company whose shitty autonomous vehicle is a safety hazard.
4 accidents by now. Zoox is another company running tests apparently. Unless GM stops/slows down tests, this is likely to go over 10 and maybe 20.

An autonomous car parked in a lot hit by someone else counts here. If it were accidents caused purely by autonomous cars, the number would be lower, but it will be all inclusive (and not requiring judgement of fault). We’re currently at 4 for January. 4*6=24. But if you’ve been to California, you see increasing numbers if these cars. Yes some variation (higher or lower month to month) but seems reasonable to assume at least 20 over 6 months. I’m in California in a couple weeks - maybe I’ll hit a couple to improve odds of being correct!

As the range is between 0-40+, the median is 20 accidents. Higher numbers of collisions should be in decreasing proportions of incidence, as corrective actions would be taken beforehand. Less than 10 is unlikely, as the numbers of autonomous vehicles have been on the rise.
In order to have approved multiple companies for testing, trials indicating that these vehicles are significantly safe must have already occurred.

4th for January. 1/28/18 Although if you read the detailed report there was no accident. It was a road rage incident? But there was minor vehicle damage. I don't know if GJ will just use the number of reports or actually parse out based on what was in the report. edit: I just re-read the question in detail "companies shall report within 10 days any accident originating from the operation of an autonomous vehicle on a public road that resulted in property damage, bodily injury or death" So I guess as long as the vehicle is on a public road any thing that causes damage is classified an accident. This means: [far higher number of tests] x [decreased probability of accident]  which I believe is supported by my proposed distribution.

Using a an estimated base rate of 4 accidents per million miles (based on human drivers).  I assumed 12000 miles per year, and 5.3 remaining months. I adjusted a bit to the high side to account for growth in the number of cars. From the base rate, I used variance of the Poisson distribution for the other categories.

Background:
If you plot out the accident report rate for 2016 and 2017, you can see that it's actually a pretty linear trend, despite the small sample sizes. The outliers are September and October 2017, which saw huge numbers of reports for GM Cruiser. However, you can see that this slows down again for the rest of the year. For the first half of 2016, the accident rate was at about 1.25/mo and the first half of 2017 saw about 1.5/mo. These trends seem to actually put the base rate at just about 10, which hilariously is right on the edge of the prediction bin. Fewer than 10:
Google/Waymo was a big driver (no pun intended) of 2016, but tech news seems to indicate that they've pulled out of California and into Arizona for testing. I haven't checked, but I wonder if it has anything to do with differences in state regulations for AV accident reporting...
[1] https://www.theverge.com/2017/11/7/16615290/waymo-self-driving-safety-driver-chandler-autonomous There's > 40 companies licensed to test AV in California, but only Google and GM are currently showing major signs of activity, and as stated above, Google is probably out. GM was the sole cause of the Sept./Oct. outliers, and they suffered some pretty bad press because of it. It looks like they started lying low and/or being more careful because there's only two from them for the rest of the year. This could be a fiscal year thing - I can imagine someone from the top axing testing until 2018 to keep the bar charts shown in the board room meetings from getting out of control. 10 to 19, inclusive:
Which brings us to the next interval. GM, for better or worse, is probably staying in California because they plan to launch a taxi service by 2019 in San Francisco [2]. Their fleet more than doubled last year to about 100 and now they have a pretty big motivation to test a lot more [3]. Now that it's 2018, they get a fiscal year clean slate, so those Sept./Oct. outliers may not be outliers in the future.
[2] https://www.theverge.com/2017/11/30/16720776/gm-cruise-self-driving-taxi-launch-2019
[3] http://fortune.com/2017/10/04/gm-self-driving-car-california/ 20 to 29, inclusive:
The above would be the total estimate IF I could assume that it'd only be GM doing testing in California, but I have to account for the possibility that another player might try to break into the field and/or GM going nuts with their testing. Another player is very unlikely - GM has deep pockets and California's strict reporting guidelines probably spook most companies, not to mention that historically there are only one or two accident reports from a company that is not Google or GM. If GM wants to set up taxis in SF, it needs to run more tests, and mileage is highly correlated with accidents for AVs (see the linked paper). On the other hand, these accident reports are very closely monitored by the press, so any spike in accidents will likely result in a decrease in testing by order of head office to modulate the numbers. This is a very wide spread, but we only have data up until Jan 7th (10-day delay), and I need to see what happens for a month or two before being more confident about trends.
Historical accidents reported are low to date.

The base rate is hard to judge, due to strong fluctuations in the last years, which are at least attributable to increased usage of Avs. The difference between H1 and H2 can partially be explained by the growth, but it seems like there are slightly less accidents in H1 on average. Due to the increase of the GM-fleet and possible influx of vehicles by other manufacturers, the number of Miles driven, which correlates extremely strong with the number of accidents, will probably increase moderately, although rather extreme increases do not seem too improbable. Since the number of vehicles seems to have already increased quite a bit since last H1, and because the number of accidents does not seem to correlate strongly with the "quality" of the AVs (at least at the level they seem to be right now), since most accidents involving them are caused by human drivers, 10 or less accidents seem to be rather unlikely, even though they correspond to the last years base rate. More than 30 accidents would probably require the number of miles covered to more than double, which is certainly possible, especially because of the rather low current number, but does not seem too likely.

Like @bmiller said, the number of accidents this year varies between H1 and H2. In fact, it's clear that the number of accidents depends on whether there are companies testing AVs in California and where they are testing the AVs. Google/Waymo apparently mostly left CA after H1, GM/Cruise started moved in and added more testing. Also GM/Cruise started testing in SF where vehicle density is higher, streets are narrower and fender benders more likely. If GM/Cruise continues testing in SF, we can expect the same number of accidents as in H2 2017. If they stop testing in SF, the number of accidents will drop to H1 numbers or lower. If other companies start testing (in SF especially), the number of accidents will rise. It is worthwhile to check what GM/Cruise testing plans for H1/2018 are and if other companies are gonna start testing in CA in H1/2018. I have not done that. Note that the number of accidents does not depend on how good AVs operate. Pretty much all accidents are fender benders caused by other (human-driven) vehicles that AVs CANNOT AVOID. I.e. side swipes, tail hits, etc. So the prediction does not depend on how good AVs are (unless some company totally unprepared for AV tests starts testing AVs), but depend principally on the number of AVs tested and location of tests (SF == more accidents, non-SF == less).
